{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3479906,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T13:43:29.769Z","cooked":"

Hi CD,

It’s been pretty standardized over the last few years to use brushless motors for all applications, but I believe this year’s challenge is calling that notion into question. For a design with an arm on an elevator, routing the extra communication wires (CAN for Neo Vortex and Kraken, sensor wire for Neo and Neo 550) just seems to be introducing extra points of failure. For motors that don’t need precise control, it seems like it would be better to send only the red and black voltage wires up the elevator, just like in the good old days.

However, it’s been a few years since I’ve looked at the options available for “dumb” motors. I haven’t been able to really follow most of the developments in this space - please forgive me for not reading CD during the offseason haha.

I also seem to remember that the pre-brushless non-CIM motors had insanely high speeds and low torques that required a lot of gearing down to be useful. They always needed hefty gearboxes, and makes me worried about weight and form factor if we decided to go the brushed route.

I’m wondering whether any of the current offerings for these types of motors and gearboxes make any sense for the application, considering the following stipulations:

  • Brushed motor
  • Lightweight (no CIM)
  • Relatively small form factor (I remember the 775Pro with VersaPlanetary gearbox being really long compared to Neo 550 and UltraPlanetary)
  • Correct speed and motor strength for fast scoring (Most servos seem too slow and too weak)

Or should we just bite the bullet with the extra wires and go brushless?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T13:43:29.769Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":57,"reads":489,"readers_count":488,"score":397.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/1","custom_user_title":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3479914,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T13:50:52.067Z","cooked":"

This is by no means an exhaustive list, but AndyMark does sell an assortmant of FRC-legal motors (most of which are brushed): Home - Electrical - Signal & Power - Motors - AndyMark, Inc

Yes, 550 and 775 style motors do have very fast output speeds and low torque ratings without gearing. Some of the above motors include gearboxes already, and some you would have to add something.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T13:50:52.067Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":458,"readers_count":457,"score":121.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/categories/motors","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Home - Electrical - Signal & Power - Motors - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":19}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3481020,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T16:53:52.758Z","cooked":"

So if you are scared of running your CAN bus that far… You can always run motors in PWM mode. This works fine for Krakens and Spark Flex. If you cut a PWM wire, you lose that motor, but not the whole bus.

Alternatively brushes motors can work well in situations like this. I personally think the redline is still a relavent motor for this sort of application. You still get 380W of power and it only weighs .8lbs. compare that to the Neo with 406W that weighs .9lbs. They have pretty similar power density. Now, the redline spins a lot faster, so you might find yourself with more gearing. For things that go fast like intake wheels, you might still be able to do it with a single stage reduction - especially with a 6t pinion available from WCP.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-13T16:53:52.758Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":396,"readers_count":395,"score":109.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Lexeo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/3","custom_user_title":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482010,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:03:00.436Z","cooked":"

How does the REV Robotics HD Hex motor perform when close to stall current, assuming it’s connected to a Spark Max with current limiting?

REV Robotics

UltraPlanetary Gearbox Kit & HD Hex Motor

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 45

Relevant motor stats:

Stall current: 8.5 amps
Stall torque: 0.105 N*m
Free speed: 6000 RPM

Consider an application where a HD Hex motor is used to grab and hold algae. If it’s attached to a compliant wheel with a 3 inch diameter, a 25:1 gear ratio would allow 37.7 inches per second of tangential speed, while pulling with a maximum tangential force of 15.5 pounds.

But I seem to remember that brushed motors have a harder time with staying near stall current, and if a weak motor like this is tasked with applying constant force to the algae in order to retain it, a previous version of myself who was more familiar with brushed motors would be anxious about burning the motor out.

Has anyone had experience with this? What is a safe value that the current limit can be set at in order to ensure that the motor doesn’t burn out? 8 amps? 5 amps? Less than that? I’m wondering about this because if the required current limit is too low, this would limit the amount of available torque and make the motor less useful for this application.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:05:28.841Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":78.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-41-1600/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"UltraPlanetary Gearbox Kit & HD Hex Motor - REV Robotics","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/4","custom_user_title":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482015,"name":"Ada T","username":"cmdada","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmdada/{size}/230870_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:12:01.003Z","cooked":"

If you plan to be stalling it, use a bag motor.
Also in our team,a experience the hd hex mini is not a good frc motor option for anything but a servo equivalent

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:12:01.003Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":235,"readers_count":234,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Ada T","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12266,"username":"John_Bottenberg","name":"John Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60586,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/5","custom_user_title":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482027,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:25:48.224Z","cooked":"

Go brushless. The reasons?

After you use a small motor (775, for instance), and gear it down to kraken speed, for weight you have:

775+Max Planetary
775: .806 lbs
Max Planetary: Base .506 lbs, 3:1 kit .341 lbs
Total: 1.6 lbs

775+Ultraplanetary
If you use a ultra planetary,
775: .806 lbs
UltraPlanetary with 3:1 cartridge: .316 lbs
Total: 1.2 lbs

Kraken
Kraken Weight: 1.2 lbs

A bag motor requires similar gearing.

The 775 has low thermal mass respectively, really doesn’t like stalling, and the ultra planetary is suspect in shock loads and high load situations because of lighter construction.

I’ll take the kraken with it’s higher thermal mass, built in current limiting availability, built in encoder, and no transmission. It also has a much shorter overall length.

It’s interesting that every time I do a comparison like this (I do it for our team quite often), I realize that the motors are just significantly better, and I can justify the extra $$ from the competitive advantage they can generate.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:36:02.152Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":228,"readers_count":227,"score":70.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/6","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482051,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:40:17.527Z","cooked":"

Brushless is better for weight, I completely agree.
Sending the CAN bus all the way up there, and outside the frame perimeter, seems risky although maybe I’m overstating the risk. Sending a Spark Max encoder wire up there is less risky than CAN, but none of the off-the-shelf extension wires are long enough and you need to either use the JST 6-pin connector board or a custom connection - potentially soldered. These connections are not bulletproof. Playing 40+ matches per year, what are the chances that something comes loose in one of those matches?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:40:17.527Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":58.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/7","custom_user_title":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482155,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T16:21:41.796Z","cooked":"

Coming loose - zero. Solder the connections. If you need to pull the motor you can unscrew it at the back.

Damaging the wires? You could go to sheathed 2 conductor twisted pair. Or use Ether cable. Or hide in the tube where you can.

If we are talking about neos with exposed spark maxes, well, mesh sleeve, zip ties, and 3D printed protection if necessary.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T16:23:29.801Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":34.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12266,"username":"John_Bottenberg","name":"John Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/8","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482183,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T16:36:21.779Z","cooked":"

You can use beefier/nicer wire for CAN signals. The manual specifies minimums, not maximums for the CAN bus (a hairline 28AWG is required)

I can’t really speak to the product, but this may be a way to get a more robust cable to critical points for a premium:

Swyft Robotics

Swyft CANnect Wiring System

Ships immediately Simplify Your Robot Wiring with the SWYFT CANnect Wiring System! Tired of complex robot wiring? SWYFT CANnect revolutionizes your setup by allowing you to run CAN bus and 12V Power over standard Ethernet cables. This drastically...

Price: USD 39.99

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T16:36:42.475Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":160,"readers_count":159,"score":32.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://swyftrobotics.com/products/swyft-cannect-wiring-system","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Swyft CANnect Wiring System – Swyft Robotics","clicks":17}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/9","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482488,"name":"M","username":"Mako","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mako/{size}/270886_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T20:36:14.319Z","cooked":"

Would Redlines be viable?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T20:36:14.319Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":44.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68890,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Hachan Supporter"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/10","custom_user_title":"Hachan Supporter","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482495,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T20:40:21.457Z","cooked":"

Yes, as long as you are not relying on (much) motor current to counter-balance the elevator (e.g. no motor feed forward). If an air cooled motor is not spinning it is not cooling. A couple seconds of stall at medium to high power levels and the smoke comes out.

Fortunately FRC has many years worth of examples on elevator counter balance with constant force (CF) springs.

You will also need some other form of sensor feedback for the elevator, but that is a solved problem. Worst case use a string pot.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T20:48:04.526Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68890,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Hachan Supporter"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/12","custom_user_title":"Hachan Supporter","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482526,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T20:52:44.519Z","cooked":"

To power the elevator.

I would probably say “use a CIM” unless you are up against space constraints. If up against space constraints and you need to go aircooled brushed: make sure you give them a chance to cool during practice.

CIM and Redline/775pro power is comparable, CIMs are much better at handling stall, and the mass is down low, therefore “healthy”.

If you need 200+ watts up the elevator then a redline may be more appealing (mass and packaging considerations), especially if you need some speed (small belt reducions rock)

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-16T20:52:25.436Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":33.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60586,"username":"cmdada","name":"Ada T","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmdada/{size}/230870_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/15","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3484951,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-16T21:09:00.973Z","cooked":"

Intake rollers don’t really need all the bells and whistles provided by smart motor controllers and CAN connections. Broadly speaking, open loop voltage control (perhaps with a current limit and/or limit switch) is more-than-adequate for controlling intake rollers and roller claws. Brushless motors are a perfectly viable solution to these types of intake devices (whether on an elevator or not).

Something like a wrist joint that needs multiple defined positions, avoid other hardware, and to react to dynamic loading (having 0, 1, or 2 game pieces) might validate the usage of a smarter motor and speed controller.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-16T21:09:00.973Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":31.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481165,"topic_slug":"dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/dumb-motors-gearboxes-for-use-on-elevator/481165/16","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3485811,"name":"Lucas Santos","username":"pucas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pucas/{size}/232495_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T18:05:39.263Z","cooked":"

I think that running extra wire up your moving superstructure to support the nicer-all-around BLDC motors that we have is the better route here. We (5514) built our robot (sort of) in this manner in 2024, and we plan our 2025 bot to be the same.

We didn’t run brushless motors on our 2024 robot barring the drivetrain, so the intake/shooter motors on our moving arm only required power leads and ran on open-loop control. However, the line-of-sight sensors we used to detect notes run on the CAN bus, so we ran our CAN loop up and down the arm to connect these, through an Ethernet cable we pillaged from somewhere. Our wiring was quite robust last season and we didn’t have any CAN issues with this. For the elevator on our 2025 bot, we plan to run four power runs for Spark MAX motor controllers, ingoing and outgoing CAN and power for our game piece sensors, much like last year. We’ll probably also run another Ethernet cable onto which we can splice a camera USB connection (for driver visibility) and something else, possibly a servo if we want. This will all run through energy chain.

Putting critical wire runs across such long and treacherous distances does introduce extra points of failure, but there are ways to mitigate the danger. Motor controllers can be run on their own individual PWN connections to the Rio, as aforementioned, so that a failure doesn’t kill the whole bus. Furthermore, doing your wiring thoroughly and diligently is maybe the greatest protection against problems. This post on 2102’s build thread is a great resource for robot wiring.

I’m kind of sad that we don’t plan on using any brushed motors this year. Sure they’re bulky, less efficient, often require gearing to obtain usable torque and lack integrated encoders, but their electrical simplicity does give fewer points of failure, and some are really resistant to stalling—especially those ever-sturdy BAG motors. But the benefits of BLDCs on our mechanisms are too big to give up. Our coral indexer couldn’t be as lightweight as it is without using Neo 550s, and the integrated encoders in NEOs make closed-loop control of elevators and arms/wrists much easier.

Keep Murphy’s Law in mind with your wiring: motors can burn out, wires can be ripped off your robot by another robot, mechanisms can stall unexpectedly, et cetera… Use current limits to protect vulnerable motors and be prepared to administer replacements. Do try to design mechanisms to minimize possible failures; if this means running brushed motors up on your elevator, excellent. But extra complexity may be worth the price of increased capability.

I hope my anecdotal contributions help in some way. I don’t mean to claim what I’ve said as purely my own as I am likely parroting some of what has already been said in this thread. Best of luck and long live the BAG motor
